Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue ".NET Core 2.1.1 SDK 2.1.301 Implicitly References Microsoft.NETCore.App 2.1.0" (#3257) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@coolcsh ,  In order to work around, add

`<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.NETCore.App" Version="2.1.1" />
`

to the project file like so:

```
<ItemGroup>
  <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.AspNetCore.App" />
  <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.NETCore.App" Version="2.1.1" />
</ItemGroup>

```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Remove support for the implicit package version of Microsoft.AspNetCore.App " (#3292) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App, unlike normal NuGet packages, represents a shared framework. This means the package provides: * A) The minimum expected version of of the ASP.NET Core shared runtime (found in C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App\$(PackageVersion)) * B) A baseline of assemblies versions which the SDK expects to find in the shared runtime * C) References assemblies for the compiler * D) Implementations assemblies for self-contained deployments There is tension between these as we want the lowest possible version of (A) to simplify deployment concerns, the highest version of (D) for security updates and patch fixes, and a version of (B) and (C) compatible with both (A) and (D). We attempted to solve this tension in 2.1.0 by optimizing for (A) and hiding the package version from users and keeping it low, pinned to 2.1.0. That [made it difficult]() to use packages which shared dependencies with the shared framework. In 2.1.1, we tried to fix this by easing off the restrictions and allowing package upgrades, but means users unintentionally upgrade out of the baseline (B), and end up with redundant copies of binaries in their publish output. After lots of design discussion reviewing half a dozen alternatives, we think it will be better in the long run to back to reverse course and encourage users to use an explicit version on the PackageReference to Microsoft.AspNetCore.App, and it regularly update it to latest. ## Proposed changes * Update `dotnet new` templates to include the latest Microsoft.AspNetCore.App package version in the .csproj file. * Update Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Web to warn when Microsoft.AspNetCore.App is missing a package version. * Text: `The package reference to Microsoft.AspNetCore.App is missing the Version attribute. Defaulting to Version="2.1.1".`. * Remove "IsImplicitlyDefined" = true from Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Web. This unblocks the NuGet UI from displaying updates. Before: After: ## Downsides One of the primary reasons for making the version implicit was to simplify deployment. As history since 2.0.0 has taught us, our users that updating a PackageReference should be sufficient to use the newest version of ASP.NET Core. However, there is one more step required: users need to install a compatible shared runtime. This step is not obvious from the NuGet Package UI in VS, and error messages indicating the missing runtime are sometimes hidden (e.g. IIS Express, Test Explorer). ## Proposed enhancement * Update Microsoft.NET.Sdk to produce a warning when compiling for a .NET Core shared framework which is not present on the machine (cc @dsplaisted @nguerrera). * Text: `This project is compiling for Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 2.1.3, but a compatible runtime was not found. .NET Core runtimes can be installed from https://aka.ms/dotnet-download` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2696087/42192301-db33105c-7e1c-11e8-912a-60b601fe7414.png) cc @DamianEdwards @davidfowl @JunTaoLuo @vijayrkn

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Update branding in master branch to 3.0, prepare release/2.2 branches" (#3278) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Per discussion with the engineering teams, we should make the following changes.

* Create a branch named "release/2.2". 
* Rename the "dev" branch to "master". This is part of aligning aspnet repos with the branch naming used by other Microsoft teams.
* Change the default branch to "master" on GitHub.
* Update the product branding on "master" to 3.0.
* Create automation to help automate PRs from release/2.2 to master when changes are made in 2.2

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Asp.Net Core 2.1: SSL from UWP app" (#3145) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I ported my WebAPI from Asp.Net Core 2.0 to release candidate 2.1.  The default template enables SSL, but I couldn't get it working.  This exception is thrown:

> System.Net.Http.HttpRequestException
  HResult=0x80072F0D
  Message=An error occurred while sending the request.
  Source=System.Net.Http
  StackTrace:
   at System.Net.Http.HttpClientHandler.<SendAsync>d__111.MoveNext()
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at System.Net.Http.HttpClient.<FinishSendAsyncBuffered>d__58.MoveNext()
Inner Exception 1:
COMException: The text associated with this error code could not be found.
The certificate authority is invalid or incorrect

How can I get SSL to work in my projects?  I'm new to working with SSL in .NET so hopefully it's easy to answer for someone familiar with it.

I thought the certificate stuff was handled by VS when I ran the project.  Since I keep getting the exception, I manually ran the following commands:

> Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.17134.48]
(c) 2018 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
> 
> C:\...\WebAPI_NoAuth>dotnet install tool dotnet-dev-certs -g --version 2.1.0-rc1-final
> 
> Welcome to .NET Core!
> ---------------------
> Learn more about .NET Core: https://aka.ms/dotnet-docs
Use 'dotnet --help' to see available commands or visit: https://aka.ms/dotnet-cli-docs
> 
> Telemetry
> ---------
> The .NET Core tools collect usage data in order to help us improve your experience. The data is anonymous and doesn't include command-line arguments. The data is collected by Microsoft and shared with the community. You can opt-out of telemetry by setting the DOTNET_CLI_TELEMETRY_OPTOUT environment variable to '1' or 'true' using your favorite shell.
> 
> Read more about .NET Core CLI Tools telemetry: https://aka.ms/dotnet-cli-telemetry
> 
> ASP.NET Core
> ------------
> Successfully installed the ASP.NET Core HTTPS Development Certificate.
To trust the certificate run 'dotnet dev-certs https --trust' (Windows and macOS only). For establishing trust on other platforms please refer to the platform specific documentation.
For more information on configuring HTTPS see https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=848054.
No executable found matching command "dotnet-install"
> 
> C:\...\WebAPI_NoAuth>dotnet dev-certs https --trust
> Trusting the HTTPS development certificate was requested. A confirmation prompt will be displayed if the certificate was not previously trusted. Click yes on the prompt to trust the certificate.
A valid HTTPS certificate is already present.

The security warning popped up and I clicked 'yes'.  Why is the same exception still thereafter thrown?  I've tried passing `new HttpClientHandler { ClientCertificateOptions = ClientCertificateOption.Automatic }` to `HttpClient`'s constructor, but alas it's always the same exception.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ConfirmEmailAsync in UserManager does a ton of unrelated actions and validations" (#1856) at aspnet/Identity
Events.RelatedBody: **`ConfirmEmailAsync`** in **`UserManager`** should validate a token and set the **`EmailConfirmed`** flag to true. However, in the current implementation, we save the context changes through invoking the **`UpdateUserAsync`** method. It re-sets the Normalized username and email and then calls the **`ValidateUserAsync`** method, which in turn runs the user validators. It is not that great of an overhead, but is this really necessary or is it just an architectural trade-off?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CPU usage spikes with new Sockets transport" (#2694) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm having a weird issue with the new "Sockets" transport and I hope you might have some ideas! 

I'm running the latest .NET Core 2.1.1 / ASP.NET Core 2.1.1. I have a single-node Service Fabric cluster for development purposes on Azure (Windows, 2 cores, 16GB RAM) and it runs ~ 60 .NET Core processes (self-contained, `win10-x64`). About half of them are ASP.NET Core applications, the rest is regular console applications with background services. The applications are communicating via the Service Fabric HTTP reverse proxy on localhost (using `HttpClient`).

As it's a dev/demo system, there's almost no load on it. However, when using the new "Sockets" transport, I get high CPU usage (50% - 100%) on the ASP.NET core apps for quite a few seconds every few minutes  which results in a very unstable system.

As you can see in the overall CPU usage of the machine, the system became much more stable after I switched back to `Libuv`. I afterwards tried `Sockets()` with one app and CPU usage became unstable again.
![cpu-overall](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42093084-6d528612-7bab-11e8-916a-628241acb5c5.png)

I've been running PerfView and it shows that the high CPU usage happens around these calls:

```
module Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core <<Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core!Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core.Internal.Http.HttpProtocol+<ProcessRequests>d__186`1[Microsoft.AspNetCore.Hosting.Internal.HostingApplication+Context].MoveNext()>>
module system.io.pipelines <<system.io.pipelines!System.IO.Pipelines.Pipe+DefaultPipeReader.ReadAsync(value class System.Threading.CancellationToken)>>
module system.io.pipelines <<system.io.pipelines!System.IO.Pipelines.Pipe+DefaultPipeReader.AdvanceTo(value class System.SequencePosition,value class System.SequencePosition)>>
```

Here's some screenshots. Calls by name:
![callsbyname](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092808-8b5ef614-7baa-11e8-8131-0eb0027ea856.png)

Call tree: 
![calltree-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092871-c4a6c92e-7baa-11e8-9903-aea9000ba569.png)
![calltree-2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092872-c7142256-7baa-11e8-90ce-758917eed3a7.png)
![calltree-3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092875-c9893742-7baa-11e8-8601-5eb8152f586a.png)

_Process CPU usage with libuv:_
As I've said there's almost no load on the app/system.
![cpu-usage-libuv](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092900-d76e3d08-7baa-11e8-98fe-bf85ee32d3c7.png)

_Process CPU usage with Sockets transport:_
Some spikes just take 1-2 seconds, others take a lot longer.
![cpu-usage-sockets](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092892-d2cd05fe-7baa-11e8-8f03-8fca0eafbbdb.png)

Any ideas on a possible cause?

PS: I don't know much about PerfView so I hope that what I've done is not misleading.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support for multi-line string values" (#1057) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @alexvy86 on August 3, 2017 21:11_

I'm using Akka.NET in a project and the way they do configuration is not-quite-JSON, but still a hierarchical structure, which I haven't been able to successfully integrate into `appsettings.json`. The only way I've been able to do it is to collapse all of their hierarchy into a single-line string value, which makes it a bit of a pain to work with.

For now I just put the whole thing as CDATA in an XML file and use the `AddXmlFile()` extension from `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Xml` to read it, but it'd be preferable to have it in `appsetings.json`.

_Copied from original issue: aspnet/Configuration#703_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Unable to publish when using Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor" (#1076) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "For contributors: branch name changes in ASP.NET Core repos" (#309) at aspnet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: Over the coming weeks, we are planning on making the following changes to most projects in https://github.com/aspnet that are used to build ASP.NET Core. * We will create a branch named "release/2.2". Work on this branch will be part of [ASP.NET Core 2.2](https://github.com/aspnet/Announcements/issues/307) * We will rename the "dev" branch to "master". This is part of aligning aspnet repos with the branch naming used by other Microsoft teams. * We will change the default branch to "master" on GitHub. * Update the product branding on "master" to 3.0. Work on this branch will eventually become part of [ASP.NET Core 3.0](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/dotnet/2018/05/07/net-core-3-and-support-for-windows-desktop-applications/) To help us prevent too much drift between release/2.2 and master, we will enable some automation to merge all changes from release/2.2 into master (3.0). ## FAQ This change may affect the way you help contribute to ASP.NET Core. As a result of this change and dicussion within our team, we've anticipated at least two questions you may have. #### Which branch should I use for my work? #### I opened my PR to the wrong branch. What should I do? You can edit a PR‚Äôs target branch. ## Questions? Comments? This issue is locked to reduce noise on this repo. Please use https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/3278 for questions and comments. Thanks, Nate

Issues.Title: Remove support for the implicit package version of Microsoft.AspNetCore.App
Issues.Body: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App, unlike normal NuGet packages, represents a shared framework. This means the package provides: * A) The minimum expected version of of the ASP.NET Core shared runtime (found in C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App\$(PackageVersion)) * B) A baseline of assemblies versions which the SDK expects to find in the shared runtime * C) References assemblies for the compiler * D) Implementations assemblies for self-contained deployments There is tension between these as we want the lowest possible version of (A) to simplify deployment concerns, the highest version of (D) for security updates and patch fixes, and a version of (B) and (C) compatible with both (A) and (D). We attempted to solve this tension in 2.1.0 by optimizing for (A) and hiding the package version from users and keeping it low, pinned to 2.1.0. That [made it difficult]() to use packages which shared dependencies with the shared framework. In 2.1.1, we tried to fix this by easing off the restrictions and allowing package upgrades, but means users unintentionally upgrade out of the baseline (B), and end up with redundant copies of binaries in their publish output. After lots of design discussion reviewing half a dozen alternatives, we think it will be better in the long run to back to reverse course and encourage users to use an explicit version on the PackageReference to Microsoft.AspNetCore.App, and it regularly update it to latest. ## Proposed changes * Update `dotnet new` templates to include the latest Microsoft.AspNetCore.App package version in the .csproj file. * Update Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Web to warn when Microsoft.AspNetCore.App is missing a package version. * Text: `The package reference to Microsoft.AspNetCore.App is missing the Version attribute. Defaulting to Version="2.1.1".`. * Remove "IsImplicitlyDefined" = true from Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Web. This unblocks the NuGet UI from displaying updates. Before: After: ## Downsides One of the primary reasons for making the version implicit was to simplify deployment. As history since 2.0.0 has taught us, our users that updating a PackageReference should be sufficient to use the newest version of ASP.NET Core. However, there is one more step required: users need to install a compatible shared runtime. This step is not obvious from the NuGet Package UI in VS, and error messages indicating the missing runtime are sometimes hidden (e.g. IIS Express, Test Explorer). ## Proposed enhancement * Update Microsoft.NET.Sdk to produce a warning when compiling for a .NET Core shared framework which is not present on the machine (cc @dsplaisted @nguerrera). * Text: `This project is compiling for Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 2.1.3, but a compatible runtime was not found. .NET Core runtimes can be installed from https://aka.ms/dotnet-download` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2696087/42192301-db33105c-7e1c-11e8-912a-60b601fe7414.png) cc @DamianEdwards @davidfowl @JunTaoLuo @vijayrkn
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Remove support for the implicit package version of Microsoft.AspNetCore.App " (#3292)

Issues.Title: Update branding in master branch to 3.0, prepare release/2.2 branches
Issues.Body:
Per discussion with the engineering teams, we should make the following changes.

* Create a branch named "release/2.2". 
* Rename the "dev" branch to "master". This is part of aligning aspnet repos with the branch naming used by other Microsoft teams.
* Change the default branch to "master" on GitHub.
* Update the product branding on "master" to 3.0.
* Create automation to help automate PRs from release/2.2 to master when changes are made in 2.2

Issues.Title: Ajax CDN is missing a bundled version of the core client library used in ASP.NET
Issues.Body:
This one is similar to: #3285 

The Bootstrap 4.* authors added version of the JavaScript Bootstrap library bundled with its core dependency for tooltips/pop-overs/etc: 'popper.js':
https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.1/getting-started/contents/#js-files

The published version of the Bootstrap on the MS Ajax CDN seems to be missing the `bundle` version:
https://ajax.aspnetcdn.com/ajax/bootstrap/4.0.0/bootstrap.js
https://ajax.aspnetcdn.com/ajax/bootstrap/4.0.0/bootstrap.bundle.js

Thanks!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Ajax CDN is missing a bundled version of the core client library used in ASP.NET " (#3290)

Issues.Title: Things may consider for Localization 3.0.0
Issues.Body:
There 're some points I'd like to share with you guys, that may we consider for localization 3.0.0:

- Move resource manager classes into a new namespace `Microsoft.Extensions.Localization.ResourceManager`, this is useful for APIs organization and if we add another localization source provider such as `POStringLocalizer` also to align with other ASP.NET Core repos such as Configuration, Security .. etc
- Use ASP.NET Core `MemoryCache` instead of using `IResourceNamesCache` & `ResourceNamesCache`, no need to reivent the wheel, while we are have a rich and tested APIs
- Using `ResourceManager` resource set directly from within `ResourceManagerStringLocalizer` instead of introducing `IResourceStringProvider` & `ResourceManagerStringProvider`. If I'm not wrong those APIs was introduced because the lack and limitation of the `ResourceManager` resource set APIs support in .NET Core in the past
- Support Pluralization APIs out-of-the-box
- Support another localization resource provider such as `POStringLocalizer`
- These are some that raised on my head and I will modify the list if I have other once

/cc @mkArtakMSFT
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Things may consider for Localization 3.0.0" (#3289)

Issues.Title: Cannot debug client-side code in VS Code with out-of-the-box SPA project.
Issues.Body:
I've created a new React SPA for ASP.NET Core 2.1.

Out of the box, if I open the `ClientApp` directory in VS Code I can then hit F5 to launch Chrome (using the Chrome debugger extension).

However, when I set breakpoints, each breakpoint is greyed out with the following message:

````
Unverified breakpoint, Breakpoints set but not yet bound
````

I'm fairly certain this is an issue with the `launch.json` configuration, specifically the `webRoot` (and possibly the `sourceMapPathOverrides`) property.

Here's the standard `launch.json` that I'm using:

````
{
    // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible attributes.
    // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
    // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "chrome",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Chrome against localhost",
            "url": "https://localhost:44311",
            "webRoot": "${workspaceFolder}",
            "sourceMapPathOverrides": {
                "webpack:///./*": "${webRoot}/*",
                "webpack:///src/*": "${webRoot}/*",
                "webpack:///*": "*",
                "webpack:///./~/*": "${webRoot}/node_modules/*",
                "meteor://üíªapp/*": "${webRoot}/*"
            }
        }
    ]
}
````

And the output of calling `.scripts` in a debug session is:

````
‚Ä∫ https://localhost:44311/static/js/bundle.js
````

Is the assumption that it's an issue with `launch.json` correct?  If so, what is the correct configuration out of the box?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Cannot debug client-side code in VS Code with out-of-the-box SPA project." (#3287)

Issues.Title: Please include deleting ASP.NET Core Runtime in Uninstaller
Issues.Body:
_From @JunTaoLuo on June 29, 2018 21:42_

_From @VSDekar on June 29, 2018 12:2_

We had huge problems with dotnet core SDK 2.1.301 so we went back to 2.1.300. But the uninstaller did not delete the ASP.NET Core runtime.

Because the runtime was still there after we uninstalled 2.1.301 we got some very strange problems.

So my expectation is, that everything that an installer installs on the system will be deleted by the uninstaller. I had to delete manually the folder in `C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App`

Thx

_Copied from original issue: dotnet/core#1740_

_Copied from original issue: aspnet/SetupSharedFramework#10_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Please include deleting ASP.NET Core Runtime in Uninstaller" (#3286)

Issues.Title: .Net Core template based on BS4 are missing core dependency on MS Ajax CDN
Issues.Body:
The ASP.NET templating team is working on update of client/design dependencies to BS4
https://github.com/aspnet/templating/pull/595

There is a problem with update in my opinion:
- the template authors use Ajax CDN for production (hosted) dependencies
- the Ajax CDN is missing core Bootstrap 4 dependency required for tooltips/pop-overs/modals, etc

e.g. see comment on this non-merged, staled PR:
https://github.com/aspnet/templating/pull/476#issue-181709995

> also upgrade libs to latest version. used cdnjs instead of the MS cdn since popper.js is missing (bs4 dependency) and because MS cdn doesn't show integrated strings.

If possible, can someone add that core dependency to Ajax CDN resources (and later update docs)?
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/ajax/cdn/overview#Bootstrap_Releases_on_the_CDN_14

To re-iterate issue: 
- some features of BS 4 depends on JavaScript
- if JavaScript components are to be used (think: business-line apps) the BS needs:
- jQuery, Popper.js and its own library ('bootstrap.js')

The page author can use`bootstrap.bundle.js` to use Popper.js bundled, but that is just an option (and she or he needs to know what is the difference between `bootstrap.js` and `bootstrap.bundle.js`)

Thanks!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ".Net Core template based on BS4 are missing core dependency on MS Ajax CDN" (#3285)

Issues.Title: .NET core - route behavior difference from Windows and Linux
Issues.Body:
I am using this route on Windows with .NET core:

```
routes.MapRoute("api", "{action}/{id?}", new { controller = "API", action = "Index" });
```

Everything works great in console app or in IIS. Example url: http://localhost/action/parameter, calls into APIController controller class.

When running the same code on Linux (Ubuntu 18.04 in this case), I get a 404 error for every call. Changing the route to this fixes it:

```
routes.MapRoute("api", "/{action}/{id?}", new { controller = "API", action = "Index" });
```

Note that the new route starts with a forward slash, which is required on Linux. It would be nice if the forward slash was optional on all platforms.

Thanks very much!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ".NET core - route behavior difference from Windows and Linux" (#3284)

Issues.Title: Update Ajax CND resources related to core ASP .NET project client dependencies
Issues.Body:
There are no related repo, it seems to be the best place.

There is an ASP MVC template update pending here:
https://github.com/aspnet/templating/pull/595
for moving web templates dependencies and design forward. 
There is a problem that version of main library used as dependency (code and design) released by library authors is current at 4.1.1:
https://www.bootstrapcdn.com/
while the version of the same library hosted by MS at Ajax CDN is still locked on the 4.0.0 (the very first version from 4.*)
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/ajax/cdn/overview#Bootstrap_Releases_on_the_CDN_14

How can we trigger some update on MS CDN?

Thanks!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Update Ajax CND resources related to core ASP .NET project client dependencies" (#3283)

Issues.Title: HttpContext.Request.Path - The path in 'value' must start with '/'.
Issues.Body:
In some cases, when someone tries to access a page which relies on `HttpContext.Request.Path`, the following error is thrown:
```
The path in 'value' must start with '/'.
```
The URL looks something like this:
```
https://www.domain.com/fiction/18594/cultivating-civilization/chapter/228753/151-traitors
```
This seems to work for most users, but with rare exceptions. I'm not sure what exact conditions trigger this, as I see no headers or such that could justify this.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "HttpContext.Request.Path - The path in 'value' must start with '/'." (#3282)

Issues.Title: After package upgrade to 2.1.1 server/app fails to start
Issues.Body:
So I just upgraded packages for ASP.NET Core (the default ones, that come with the project template) from 2.1.0 to 2.1.1 and suddenly the app did not start again..

Found the following error in event log:
Application 'MACHINE/WEBROOT/APPHOST/TRIP.ADMIN' with physical root 'H:\...\App.Admin\' failed to start process with commandline 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Community\Common7\IDE\Extensions\Microsoft\Web Tools\ProjectSystem\VSIISExeLauncher.exe -argFile "C:\Users\Marko\AppData\Local\Temp\tmp4D17.tmp"', ErrorCode = '0x80004005 : 0.

Then tried some Google searches and stumled upon this
https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/24412/dotnetexe-instantly-crashes-when-debugging-aspnet.html

saying that it could be SDK related so I went and installed SDK 2.1.301 on the machine (previously had 2.1.300 running) and now magically the app works.

My question is: whatever happened to saying that ASP.NET Core is self contained and we don't have to worry about updating computers/servers? I guess it's not quite like that, ha..
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "After package upgrade to 2.1.1 server/app fails to start" (#3281)

Issues.Title: [question] angular project should be in same project or separate
Issues.Body:
I was reading how the angular template is implemented, I am seeing that the frontend is sitting in the same project, I wonder if it's the recommended way of architecting the angular project with asp.net core or not? 

in cloud architecture, it's good to separate part of an application to scale separately, but since the frontend really doesn't cost much to server files it usually end up to host on same server. 
what are the benefits that i should expect from keeping the angular and .net together?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[question] angular project should be in same project or separate" (#3280)

Issues.Title: Diagnostic Logs Level set in Azure does not work
Issues.Body:
We are running an ASP.NET Core 2.1 app in Azure App Service with logging set in appsettings.Development.json and apnetcore_environment set to development. We have noticed that when we make a change to the Diagnostic Logs Level it does not make a difference in the logging output. We‚Äôve tested this looking at the Log Stream output and with/without application restarts. Is this supposed to be the preferred behavior? In the documentation it seems to imply this should work ok without any code changes in .NET Core (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/fundamentals/logging/?view=aspnetcore-2.1&tabs=aspnetcore2x#azure-app-service-provider).

From the docs: 
‚ÄúIf targeting .NET Core, don't install the provider package or explicitly call AddAzureWebAppDiagnostics. The provider is automatically available to the app when the app is deployed to Azure App Service.

When you deploy to an App Service app, the app honors the settings in the Diagnostic Logs section of the App Service page of the Azure portal. When these settings are updated, the changes take effect immediately without requiring a restart or redeployment of the app.‚Äù
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Diagnostic Logs Level set in Azure does not work" (#3279)

Issues.Title: Simplifying default VS Dockerfile
Issues.Body:
I have created a new .Net Core-based ASP.NET Core project and chose Linux-based support for Docker:

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/287848/41993984-4777f954-7a4d-11e8-97cd-15f221a2489b.png)

When I did that, the Dockerfile that was generated was:

```dockerfile
FROM microsoft/dotnet:2.1-aspnetcore-runtime AS base
WORKDIR /app
EXPOSE 49357
EXPOSE 44389

FROM microsoft/dotnet:2.1-sdk AS build
WORKDIR /src
COPY WebApplication1/WebApplication1.csproj WebApplication1/
RUN dotnet restore WebApplication1/WebApplication1.csproj
COPY . .
WORKDIR /src/WebApplication1
RUN dotnet build WebApplication1.csproj -c Release -o /app

FROM build AS publish
RUN dotnet publish WebApplication1.csproj -c Release -o /app

FROM base AS final
WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=publish /app .
ENTRYPOINT ["dotnet", "WebApplication1.dll"]
```

It seems to me that this is unnecessarily complicated. What is the reason for having having separate `base` and `build` layers? And why run `dotnet build` explicitly, when `dotnet publish` runs it implicitly?

Put differently, couldn't the Dockerfile be simplified to the following?

```dockerfile
FROM microsoft/dotnet:2.1-sdk AS publish
WORKDIR /src
COPY WebApplication1/WebApplication1.csproj WebApplication1/
RUN dotnet restore WebApplication1/WebApplication1.csproj
COPY . .
WORKDIR /src/WebApplication1
RUN dotnet publish WebApplication1.csproj -c Release -o /app

FROM microsoft/dotnet:2.1-aspnetcore-runtime
WORKDIR /app
EXPOSE 49357
EXPOSE 44389
COPY --from=publish /app .
ENTRYPOINT ["dotnet", "WebApplication1.dll"]
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Simplifying default VS Dockerfile" (#3273)

Issues.Title: Allow data protection without writable storage
Issues.Body:
I have a server farm in where I have no writable storage (no redis, fileshare, or database) but I would like to use the `IDataProtectionProvider` interfaces.  One node will be sending data to another transitively through a 3rd-party.

Is there an implementation of `IDataProtectionProvider` that does not use the key-rotation logic that requires a writable storage?

I know of the `EphemeralDataProtectionProvider` which doesn't require a store, but this is useless in a server farm scenario.  All other implementations look to require storing it in a filesystem, in azure, in redis, or whatever else.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow data protection without writable storage" (#3272)

Issues.Title: No AccountController and ManageController from auth Individual template
Issues.Body:
Submitted by @retifrav in https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/1731

-----------------

# No AccountController and ManageController from auth Individual template

Template

```
dotnet new mvc --auth Individual
```

no longer provides `AccountController` and `ManageController`.

## Description

With host version 2.0.5 this template generates those controllers and with host version 2.1.0 it does not. See the listings below.

### Host 2.0.5

```
$ dotnet --info
.NET Command Line Tools (2.1.4)

Product Information:
 Version:            2.1.4
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  5e8add2190

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Mac OS X
 OS Version:  10.13
 OS Platform: Darwin
 RID:         osx.10.12-x64
 Base Path:   /usr/local/share/dotnet/sdk/2.1.4/

Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host

  Version  : 2.0.5
  Build    : 17373eb129b3b05aa18ece963f8795d65ef8ea54
```

Folder structure after `dotnet new mvc --auth Individual`:

```
$ tree
.
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Controllers
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ AccountController.cs
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ HomeController.cs
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ManageController.cs
...
```

### Host 2.1.0

```
$ dotnet --info
.NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json):
 Version:   2.1.300
 Commit:    adab45bf0c

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     ubuntu
 OS Version:  16.04
 OS Platform: Linux
 RID:         ubuntu.16.04-x64
 Base Path:   /usr/share/dotnet/sdk/2.1.300/

Host (useful for support):
  Version: 2.1.0
  Commit:  caa7b7e2ba

.NET Core SDKs installed:
  2.1.300 [/usr/share/dotnet/sdk]
```

Folder structure after `dotnet new mvc --auth Individual`:

```
$ tree
.
|-- Controllers
|   `-- HomeController.cs
...
```

## Question

Was this change intentional?
If yes, then how does one gets those controllers generated with host version 2.1.0 (or later)?
If no, then I guess it is a bug.

*If I chose the wrong tracker to report this issue, sorry for that and please guide me to the right one.*
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "No AccountController and ManageController from auth Individual template" (#3270)

Issues.Title: Deploying ASP.NET Core from git with kudu fails because of locked pdb file
Issues.Body:
Moved from https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/1721 - opened by @ellern. PTAL @pakrym. cc @muratg 

------------------------------

I got a couple of web apps running .NET Core 2.1.0 on different Azure service plans running on Windows. 

Lately I've started getting a file locked error when deploying from git on Azure. Almost every single time I push, it errors out telling me the file (Site.Views.pdb) is in use. Restart app, redeploy works every time, but it's annoying. I found out if I push two changes within a short timespan then there is no lock on the pdb file and the deployment works as expected.

Remote debugging is disabled for the web apps, so I have no idea why there is a lock on the pdb file.

I can't remember having any issues before I updated my web apps to .NET Core 2.0.0

```
KuduSync.NET from: 'D:\local\Temp\8d5d80c09bb9d1c' to: 'D:\home\site\wwwroot'
Error: Failed to change file that is currently being used "D:\home\site\wwwroot\Site.Web.Views.pdb"
Copying file: 'Site.Web.deps.json'
Copying file: 'Site.Web.runtimeconfig.json'
Copying file: 'Site.Web.Views.dll'
Copying file: 'Site.Web.Views.pdb'
Failed exitCode=1, command="kudusync" -v 50 -f "D:\local\Temp\8d5d80c09bb9d1c" -t "D:\home\site\wwwroot" -n "D:\home\site\deployments\c764c8a77ef871df3f13953049f5bc51088cac1f\manifest" -p "D:\home\site\deployments\bd8a3c2f17acba1e45b1c14276d9530f24e5a649\manifest" -i ".git;.hg;.deployment;deploy.cmd"
An error has occurred during web site deployment.
Error: Failed to change file that is currently being used "D:\home\site\wwwroot\Site.Web.Views.pdb"\r\nD:\Program Files (x86)\SiteExtensions\Kudu\74.10611.3437\bin\Scripts\starter.cmd "D:\home\site\deployments\tools\deploy.cmd"
```

![screen shot 2018-06-22 at 09 01 15](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4930511/41796425-c3d23612-7666-11e8-965b-a99180d6853b.png)

This issue is copied from projectkudu/kudu#2788
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Deploying ASP.NET Core from git with kudu fails because of locked pdb file" (#3269)

Issues.Title: Disabling Cookie Encryption
Issues.Body:
Is there any way to opt out of certain functionalities from the DataProtection stack?

In my case, I'm looking to opt-out of cookie encryption for my web app since it runs in a server farm. I understand there are readily available instructions for handling this scenario, e.g. storing the Data Protection key in a centralized location. In addition to that, disabling data protection is a security concern. However I can handle cookie encryption through my load balancer, which allows my app to not worry about the location and handling of the data protection keyring,

Based on previous discussions, i.e. https://github.com/aspnet/DataProtection/issues/192, it doesn't look like there's any simple way of opting out other than re-implementing the Data Protection stack myself.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Disabling Cookie Encryption" (#3263)

Issues.Title: Shared framework package introduces invisible dependencies through namespace pollution
Issues.Body:
I was just upgrading a project to use the `.App` shared framework instead of individual package references when I noticed a problem there. In my code, I have been using a `ClaimsPrincipal.FindFirstValue` extension method which I added to my project. The same extension method is also part of Identity in `Microsoft.Extensions.Identity.Core`.

By switching to the shared framework, this caused my project to throw ambigous call compiler errors since both (identical) extension methods are in the same namespace. Not a big problem as I can just remove my own implementation. However, doing so will make me use the one in `Identity.Core` and as such add an unwanted hard reference to that assembly that previously did not exist.

Now, you could argue that the shared framework will make this a non-issue since the package is available on the machine anyway. And in a way I agree with that. It‚Äôs also not that the package itself has a lot of other stuff that would cause additional problems. But it‚Äôs still another dependency my project has, and I dislike this outcome on principle. It‚Äôs not an uncommon practice within ASP.NET Core that packages have extension methods for types outside of their own namespaces. So this is really a kind of namespace pollution that has the bad side effect of introducing dependencies invisibly through the shared framework.

I do realize that there isn‚Äôt much we can do about this now, but I am really unhappy that this is another complication the shared framework causes me. I‚Äôm currently considering to completely pass on the shared framework in all my projects because of all the issues (or at least questions) its magic raises (e.g. [this](https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/3156)). And I think that‚Äôs a real shame since the intention was really good.

I don‚Äôt know how I would ideally like to see this issue get resolved. I guess I would be happy if this problem (among those others) would be considered for future iterations of the shared framework so using it becomes less problematic. Maybe there could be some opt-out mechanism for packages or something.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Shared framework package introduces invisible dependencies through namespace pollution" (#3264)

Issues.Title: Client sends data to server, but does not receive
Issues.Body:
- AspNetCore.SignalR v. 1.0.0
- .NetClient
- 4G internet connection on Windows 10 IoT Core (10.0.17134.112)
- Server has the same version of SignalR - hosted on Azure

Cannot provide many details since I don't have any relevant logs nor I was debugging.

The server did not get called OnDisconnectAsync for that connection, however the client did not receive data. 
On the other hand, the server did receive data sent by the client.

Needless to say that during this period the client responded to pings and I also accesed other services on it (WEB interface for management).

Did anyone ever encountered such a behavior?

A restart of the process, resolved the issue.

Issues.Title: On Overloads for Java Client
Issues.Body:
Making the client more usable!
Adding on overloads for the java client so you can register callbacks that can take more than one argument from an invocation.

One thing to note
In Java there's no way to get the runtime type of a generic. So in C#  where we do
```csharp
hubConnection.On<String>("Foo",  message => {...}
```
We don't have to pass in the class because we can extract that information from the generic. Since we can't do that in Java, the code looks like this
```java
hubConnection.On("Foo", (message) -> { ... }, String.class);
```
It's a little different but ultimately to the user, they still only declare each type once.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "On Overloads for Java Client" (#2568)

Next, I added SignalR by following the getting started guide from the docs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/tutorials/signalr?view=aspnetcore-2.1&tabs=visual-studio

Issues.Title: SignalR + Redis pub\sub client for any .Net application
Issues.Body:
Hi everybody,

Could you please implement the package that allows to publish notifications from any .net application to redis pub\sub so the connected asp.net core signalr application can see and process these messages on its end.

I have provided more details here: [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51058040/signalr-core-with-redis-pub-sub-and-console-application](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51058040/signalr-core-with-redis-pub-sub-and-console-application)

I see that there is some infrastructure information like headers, type of message etc. in the redis signalr contract that makes it difficult to emulate using pure redis pub\sub client.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "SignalR + Redis pub\sub client for any .Net application" (#2566)

Issues.Title: Client disconnects after 15 minutes
Issues.Body:
Server version: Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR 1.0.1
Client version: Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Client 1.0.1

Using C# client
Server: Kestrel on Pivotal Cloud Foundry instance
Client: Kestrel on Pivotal Cloud Foundry instance

Server OS: Linux
Client OS: Linux

Browser: None

I am attempting to deploy some AspNet Core 2.1 workloads on Pivotal Cloud Foundry, and testing SignalR as a mechanism for back end communication between instances.

I'm noticing an odd behavior from Clients running on PCF. After exactly 15 minutes of connecting, they will disconnect from the server. The server registers a OnDisconnectedAsync event from the connection id. However, from the client side, the Closed event is not fired.

I have tried to use the KeepAlive interval, as well as manually sending pings from the client to server.

However, at times this does not happen. The client is able to stay connected indefinitely. If I run the client from my local windows machine, this problem does not happen either.

My question: 
1. Is there anywhere in the settings which defaults to 15 minutes that I can override?
2. Has anyone else seen this behavior outside of Pivotal i.e. cloud instances running on linux

Thanks.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Client disconnects after 15 minutes" (#2565)

Issues.Title: Typescript client unable to negotiate due to unnecessary (?) JSON.parse
Issues.Body:
* Versions of Server-Side NuGet Packages: 1.0.1
* Versions of Client-Side NuGet/NPM Packages: @aspnet-signalr 1.0.0
* Are you using the C# client or the JavaScript client: TypeScript client
* The Server you are using (Kestrel/HttpSysServer/IIS/IIS Express/Azure Web App/etc.):  Azure Web App
* The Operating System on the Server (Windows/Linux/macOS): -
* The Operating System on the Client (Windows/Linux/macOS): Android (NativeScript)
* The Browser on the client, if using the JavaScript client (IE/Chrome/Edge/Firefox/etc.): -

```
JS: Debug: Starting HubConnection.
JS: Debug: Starting connection with transfer format 'Text'.
JS: Debug: Sending negotiation request: http://theapp.azurewebsites.net/gameHub/negotiate
JS: Error: Failed to complete negotiation with the server: SyntaxError: Unexpected token o in JSON at position 1
JS: Error: Failed to start the connection: SyntaxError: Unexpected token o in JSON at position 1
```

Using fiddler, I was able to see that the response from the server was correct.
This row in **HttpConnection.ts** was trying to parse the string `[Object object]`:
```
return JSON.parse(response.content as string) as INegotiateResponse;
```

Changing this row to:
```
return response.content as INegotiateResponse;
```

Solved everything for me:
```
JS: Debug: Skipping transport 'WebSockets' because it is not supported in your environment.'
JS: Debug: Skipping transport 'ServerSentEvents' because it is not supported in your environment.'
JS: Debug: Selecting transport 'LongPolling'
JS: Debug: Sending handshake request.
JS: Debug: Server handshake complete.
JS: Information: Using HubProtocol 'json'.
JS: Hub connection started
```

So the question is, is this JSON parse necessary? Should I create a pull request with this change?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Typescript client unable to negotiate due to unnecessary (?) JSON.parse" (#2562)

Issues.Title: Server Timeout in JavaScript Client doesnt work as expected
Issues.Body:
Hi guys,

I am currently developing an internal application that needs to know when the connection to my SignalR server is lost. My goal is to react to a lost connection in up to 3 seconds.

So I set the `serverTimeoutInMilliseconds` to 3000 and the 'KeepAliveInterval' to `TimeSpan.FromSeconds(1)`.

But this doesn't work as expected.
For a test I send every second a message to the client, when I walk far enough away from my WiFi 
access point my Surface stops getting messages for 20+ seconds and then I am getting a onclose event.

If test this with my Android Phone running Chrome the onclose message is almost immediately fired when the signal is lost.

Maybe this this the way Windows handles lost network connections, but if I set the `serverTimeoutInMilliseconds` this shouldn't be a problem, right?

Thanks for this great project!

### Please include as much of the following as you can in your bug report

* Versions of Server-Side NuGet Packages: tried 1.0.0 and 1.0.1
* Versions of Client-Side NuGet/NPM Packages: 1.0.0
* Are you using the C# client or the JavaScript client: Javascript
* The Server you are using (Kestrel/HttpSysServer/IIS/IIS Express/Azure Web App/etc.): Visual Studio Debug so I think Kestrel
* The Operating System on the Server (Windows/Linux/macOS): Windows
* The Operating System on the Client (Windows/Linux/macOS): Windows 10
* The Browser on the client, if using the JavaScript client (IE/Chrome/Edge/Firefox/etc.): Firefox 60 and Chrome 67
* Please use the Diagnostics Guide at https://github.com/aspnet/SignalR/wiki/Diagnostics-Guide to collect server-side and client-side logs and network traces if possible. Please **do not** put the traces and logs in the Issue text as they are quite large. The Diagnostics Guide describes how to attach them to the issue.
[Chrome_IP_Removed.txt](https://github.com/aspnet/SignalR/files/2144983/Chrome_IP_Removed.txt)

When in doubt, feel free to file the issue, we're happy to help answer questions. We also suggest using the `asp.net-core-signalr` tag on StackOverflow to ask questions.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Server Timeout in JavaScript Client doesnt work as expected" (#2557)

Issues.Title: Throw a useful error when authorization fails
Issues.Body:
When authorization fails in the JS client the error we get is "Error". Super useful üòÑ .

We should detect when authentication fails and throw a useful error like "Authentication failed". The easiest way to detect this is if the negotiate request returns `401`. Also, the transports should individually try to detect similar failures and throw the same error, in case authentication fails mid-connection.

Might need something similar in the .NET Client.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Throw a useful error when authorization fails" (#2553)

Issues.Title: ConfirmEmailAsync in UserManager does a ton of unrelated actions and validations
Issues.Body: **`ConfirmEmailAsync`** in **`UserManager`** should validate a token and set the **`EmailConfirmed`** flag to true. However, in the current implementation, we save the context changes through invoking the **`UpdateUserAsync`** method. It re-sets the Normalized username and email and then calls the **`ValidateUserAsync`** method, which in turn runs the user validators. It is not that great of an overhead, but is this really necessary or is it just an architectural trade-off?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ConfirmEmailAsync in UserManager does a ton of unrelated actions and validations" (#1856)

Issues.Title: Documentation for two factor (2FA) TOTP support
Issues.Body:
ASP.NET Identity 2.x includes support for two factor TOTP authentication using an authenticator on the smartphone. I couldn't find it documented anywhere. All I could find is configuring two factor auth with SMS Code, even though the docs specifically refer to TOTP as more appropriate:

From [docs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/security/authentication/identity-enable-qrcodes?view=aspnetcore-2.1):
>  Two factor authentication (2FA) authenticator apps, using a Time-based One-time Password Algorithm (TOTP), are the industry recommended approach for 2FA. 2FA using TOTP is preferred to SMS 2FA.

Since TOTP does not need to be configured separately and is included by default in identity razor class library, it is not a big issue, but I suppose it would make sense to document that:

* it is enabled by default
* how to disable it
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Documentation for two factor (2FA) TOTP support" (#1850)

Issues.Title: Scaffolding Identity code?
Issues.Body:
Hey guys, quick question. One of the older blogs ([this one](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/webdev/2018/03/02/aspnetcore-2-1-identity-ui/)) mentions that we should be able to also scaffold the "old" Identity (like normal controllers and views to which are all sensible and sane MVC people used to) - quoting the linked post:

> If you want the flexibility of having the identity code in your app, you can use the new identity scaffolder to add it back.

So at least that is how I understood it. Is this already implemented, has it been dropped or what? If it is a thing already, how can I access it when creating a new project? Or is there at least any real explanation of the changes, how does this new Identity UI work and how to use it? You don't possibly expect all users to read through your repo and API just to understand how to create and extend a damn login or basic application user functionality, do you?

_As a little friendly side note, reworking a thing like Identity so much from 2.0 to 2.1 without an obvious reason or any gains from user perspective and releasing it with piss-poor documentation is probably one of the main causes why so many people are still reluctant to transition to Core. This instability, fluctuation and immaturity of Core is just killing._
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Scaffolding Identity code?" (#1840)

I do have an override for `OnRefreshingPrincipal` though for the purpose of user impersonation; does this method maybe have a default value that I'm overriding that's meant to pull the claims from the store? Or am I missing something?

Issues.Title: Razor Pages _ViewImports documentation could be more clear
Issues.Body:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/mvc/razor-pages/?view=aspnetcore-2.1&tabs=visual-studio#using-layouts-partials-templates-and-tag-helpers-with-razor-pages

The part of this documentation that details the `@namespace` declaration could be made more clear. It has led some people to believe `@namespace` should be used as though it is a `using` statement. See the linked StackOverflow answer below for an example of this. I believe part of the reason it isn't clear, is because it doesn't explain `@using` directives in the context of a `_ViewImports` file.

In short, the wording could be made more clear, and a section should be added detailing `@using` directives in the context of a `_ViewImports` file.

Issues.Title: CPU usage spikes with new Sockets transport
Issues.Body:
I'm having a weird issue with the new "Sockets" transport and I hope you might have some ideas! 

I'm running the latest .NET Core 2.1.1 / ASP.NET Core 2.1.1. I have a single-node Service Fabric cluster for development purposes on Azure (Windows, 2 cores, 16GB RAM) and it runs ~ 60 .NET Core processes (self-contained, `win10-x64`). About half of them are ASP.NET Core applications, the rest is regular console applications with background services. The applications are communicating via the Service Fabric HTTP reverse proxy on localhost (using `HttpClient`).

As it's a dev/demo system, there's almost no load on it. However, when using the new "Sockets" transport, I get high CPU usage (50% - 100%) on the ASP.NET core apps for quite a few seconds every few minutes  which results in a very unstable system.

As you can see in the overall CPU usage of the machine, the system became much more stable after I switched back to `Libuv`. I afterwards tried `Sockets()` with one app and CPU usage became unstable again.
![cpu-overall](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42093084-6d528612-7bab-11e8-916a-628241acb5c5.png)

I've been running PerfView and it shows that the high CPU usage happens around these calls:

```
module Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core <<Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core!Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core.Internal.Http.HttpProtocol+<ProcessRequests>d__186`1[Microsoft.AspNetCore.Hosting.Internal.HostingApplication+Context].MoveNext()>>
module system.io.pipelines <<system.io.pipelines!System.IO.Pipelines.Pipe+DefaultPipeReader.ReadAsync(value class System.Threading.CancellationToken)>>
module system.io.pipelines <<system.io.pipelines!System.IO.Pipelines.Pipe+DefaultPipeReader.AdvanceTo(value class System.SequencePosition,value class System.SequencePosition)>>
```

Here's some screenshots. Calls by name:
![callsbyname](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092808-8b5ef614-7baa-11e8-8131-0eb0027ea856.png)

Call tree: 
![calltree-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092871-c4a6c92e-7baa-11e8-9903-aea9000ba569.png)
![calltree-2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092872-c7142256-7baa-11e8-90ce-758917eed3a7.png)
![calltree-3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092875-c9893742-7baa-11e8-8601-5eb8152f586a.png)

_Process CPU usage with libuv:_
As I've said there's almost no load on the app/system.
![cpu-usage-libuv](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092900-d76e3d08-7baa-11e8-98fe-bf85ee32d3c7.png)

_Process CPU usage with Sockets transport:_
Some spikes just take 1-2 seconds, others take a lot longer.
![cpu-usage-sockets](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092892-d2cd05fe-7baa-11e8-8f03-8fca0eafbbdb.png)

Any ideas on a possible cause?

PS: I don't know much about PerfView so I hope that what I've done is not misleading.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "CPU usage spikes with new Sockets transport" (#2694)

Issues.Title: Memory limits for embedded server
Issues.Body:
We run several game servers and are trying out kestrel as a way to access stats and perform requests on each server, we do this by embedding kestrel in our normal console app ( net core 2.1 )

The problem we have is that kestrel will eat all of the memory it can get its hands on and if we disable server GC we get other issues with GC causing slowdowns for the game server due to cpu spikes.

Is there any way to run kestrel and define an internal limit for memory? or stop it from just using everything it can find? We need to have a large amount of free memory for the game to run well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Memory limits for embedded server" (#2688)

Issues.Title: Kestrel as a service in Centos 7 .netCore 2.1
Issues.Body:
I am using a centos 7 distribution and i just updated the .netcore sdk to 2.1.301. After the update I have a strang behaivior.:
If my app is runing with dotnet run from cli or console it run as expected and static files are displayed.
If the app is run from Kestrel as a service the app does not find the static files(images/js files) or see them as html/text (css files).
The errors that I'm getting in web browser console are:
Refused to apply style from 'http://localhost:5000/css/site.css' because its MIME type ('text/html') is not a supported stylesheet MIME type, and strict MIME checking is enabled
Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404 (Not Found) - for images and js files.

I have tried to add Microsoft.AspNetCore.StaticFiles as a package but with no luck.

I have to mention that I did not change the code after upgrade. I had to upgrade the sdk to .net 2.1 because I am using NWebsec.  

kestrel service configuration looks like this:
`   [Unit]
    Description=Example .NET Web API Application running on CentOS 7

    [Service]

    ExecStart=/usr/bin/dotnet /home/user/Release/Website.dll
    Restart=always
    # Restart service after 10 seconds if dotnet service crashes
    RestartSec=10
    SyslogIdentifier=dotnet-example
    User=radu
    Environment=ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT=Production 

    [Install]
    WantedBy=multi-user.target`
As a side note /usr/bin/dotnet is linked to /usr/shared/dotnet/dotnet.
The project was published with dotnet publish -o home/user/Release/ -c Release
I don't understand what is the difference  when I run the app with dotnet run and as a service.

Any ideas how can I make this work?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Kestrel as a service in Centos 7 .netCore 2.1" (#2687)

Issues.Title: Do not send headers or data to reset h2 streams.
Issues.Body:
#2462 @halter73 I still need to finish the logging and error messages, but I wanted to show you the concept first.
Once the client has sent us a reset for a given stream we should stop sending headers or data on that stream. The request continues normally and OnStarting still triggers, you only see the error if you check RequestAborted or pass a cancellable token to WriteAsync.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Do not send headers or data to reset h2 streams." (#2686)

Issues.Title: Kestrel functional tests are flakier in the Win10-Universe build configuration
Issues.Body:
Not sure if this is an issue with the build configuration or the tests themselves. But http://aspnetci/viewType.html?buildTypeId=XPlat_Windows_Win10Universe&tab=buildTypeHistoryList shows recent builds have almost all failed with test failures in the `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.FunctionalTests` namespace.

The failures are not particularly consistent beyond their shared namespace / test project. For example `AddressRegistrationTests` holds many of the failing tests. But, that test class isn't among the culprits for all failed builds and the individual tests vary quite a lot.

I've also seen that some of the sometimes-failing tests are flakier in this particular configuration. For example, http://aspnetci/project.html?projectId=XPlat&testNameId=5785442856196240460&tab=testDetails shows that `AddressRegistrationTests.DefaultsServerAddress_BindsToIPv4` passes 99.8% of the time in all Test build configurations. That rate drops to 98.6% when focusing only on Win10-Universe (http://aspnetci/project.html?tab=testDetails&testNameId=5785442856196240460&projectId=XPlat&buildTypeId=XPlat_Windows_Win10Universe). The success rate also looks much worse in builds from the 21st on.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Kestrel functional tests are flakier in the Win10-Universe build configuration" (#2685)

Issues.Title: Lowercase logic modifies non-letter characters in header names
Issues.Body: The current logic applies the lowercase mask: https://github.com/aspnet/KestrelHttpServer/blob/dev/src/Kestrel.Core/Internal/Http2/HPack/HPackEncoder.cs#L144. But this logic does not check whether the character is a letter and can change non-letter symbols. For example, it would change `^` to `~` in header names. The fix would be to ensure that the lower case mask is only applied for upper case letters. We can also consider checking for invalid characters in the header here as well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Lowercase logic modifies non-letter characters in header names" (#2684)

Issues.Title: Use Huffman code in HPackEncoder
Issues.Body: Currently we are using a direct encoding when we encode headers. We can optimize by using Huffman code: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7541#section-2.4.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Use Huffman code in HPackEncoder" (#2683)

Issues.Title: Support HTTP/2 response headers with END_STREAM, no body
Issues.Body: If the response completes without a body there's no reason to send a data frame. Flush the headers with an End_Stream flag.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Support HTTP/2 response headers with END_STREAM, no body" (#2678)

Issues.Title: Prevent app code from blocking the connection loop
Issues.Body:
#2657 Each connection is multiplexed and has a loop that reads and processes frames. That processing must not ever get blocked by application code.

I fixed one code path where the initial request is dispatched to the app synchronously and the connection loop may get blocked by app code.

The only other case I found is for RST frames. https://github.com/aspnet/KestrelHttpServer/issues/2462#issuecomment-397702247. RequestAborted is dispatched on a background thread but that can be affected by ApplicationSchedulingMode. What's the guidance for ApplicationSchedulingMode? Should Inline mode assume the developer is going to write ideal code and never block the app loop? Or are there some conditions where we don't trust the app enough and always offload to a background thread like with the initial request above?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Prevent app code from blocking the connection loop " (#2670)

Issues.Title: Add TLS filter sample
Issues.Body:
This is the last part of HTTP/2 TLS restrictions #2251 
- SHOULD NOT use any of the cipher suites that are listed in the cipher suite black list

Since this is a SHOULD we don't want to add a hardcoded prohibition for it. The list is also 12 pages long and would be expensive to check on each request. Users are better off configuring their TLS provider to refuse these ciphers, but if they need to check for some specific ones they can do that as shown in this sample. 

@blowdart does this look workable?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add TLS filter sample" (#2675)

Issues.Title: Huge byte[] allocations in Large Object Heap after big load
Issues.Body:
Hi

I am playing with performance tests for my app. It uses AspNet.Core  + Kestrel ver. 1.1.2. Response size is pretty big, in average about 2MB, so app takes a lot of memory during testing. But what is strange, it doesn't free memory even if testing is completed. Profiler shows a big amount of byte arrays referenced by MemoryChunk and MemoryPool. 
Is there a way to reduce pool size if the app in the standby state?  Maybe some configs exist? What is the common strategy for Kestrel in this case? Should it keep allocated bytes forever? 
Also, app throws OutOfMemory from time to time, is there some kind of limit for pool size, I would prefer to drop connection rather than lost my app at all on huge load,

Thank you in advance.
Ihor
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Huge byte[] allocations in Large Object Heap after big load" (#2673)

Issues.Title: ThrowResponseAlreadyStartedException while setting StatusCode in a Controller method
Issues.Body:
My use case is pretty simple, I have a method from an asp.net core 2.1 controller that is call for a given `post` request. 

All I want to do is write some binary data in the `Response.Body` and set the `Response.StatusCode`.

No matter what I try it throws a `ThrowResponseAlreadyStartedException` stating: 

`StatusCode cannot be set because the response has already started.`

All I want to do is something like this:

```csharp
Response.ContentType = "application/octet-stream";
Response.Body.Write(someData, 0, someData.Length);
Response.StatusCode = (int) HttpStatusCode.OK;
```
Maybe I'm not using the right way to write binary data in the Response's body but that's the only one I came up with. Changing the signature of my method to return `Task<ActionResult<byte[]>>` won't do the trick to return binary data.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ThrowResponseAlreadyStartedException while setting StatusCode in a Controller method" (#2667)

Issues.Title: Fix HTTP/2 abort logic so it works despite backpressure
Issues.Body:
Using Pipe APIs as the sole means to abort a connection does not work reliably if there is no guarantee that the pipe consumer will ever stop experiencing backpressure.

This is relevant to the current HTTP/2 implementation because Http2Connection.Abort() calls through to [Http2FrameWriter.Abort()](https://github.com/aspnet/KestrelHttpServer/blob/14f020cf11c0d79472c9080064c8899e52c24b3c/src/Kestrel.Core/Internal/Http2/Http2FrameWriter.cs#L35-L48) which tries to abort the connection simply by calling PipeReader.CancelPendingRead() and PipeWriter.Complete(Exception).

Neither CancelPendingRead nor Complete will be observed by a transport that is experiencing backpressure because there is no pending ReadAsync call. Kestrel's libuv transport used to try to sidestep this issue by attaching an OnWriterCompleted callback, but even that proved insufficient because there was no way to abort the connection after the output had been completely buffered by the pipe and PipeWriter.Complete() had been called. Additionally, any connection adapters such as the one used to support SSL would prevent the transport's OnWriterCompleted callback from firing even when the output hadn't yet been completely buffered.

This issue was ultimately fixed for HTTP/1.1 by [this change](https://github.com/aspnet/KestrelHttpServer/commit/b0e1fa5e30fd3da74273d5117226f9a6073e8257#diff-4726ad98c86a27391cc7174486a258c1R194) which calls through to a new Abort() API implemented directly by the transports rather than trying to use Pipe APIs for that purpose. It's also important to note that the same change tracks the completion of the output pipe's reader loop to ensure it doesn't stall indefinitely trying to flush buffered data after a graceful call to PipeWriter.Complete().

We will have to make a similar fix for HTTP/2 connections before we can ship it.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Fix HTTP/2 abort logic so it works despite backpressure" (#2672)

Issues.Title: [RazorSdk]: Compilation is not deterministic
Issues.Body:
From https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/issues/7975

#### Is this a Bug or Feature request?: Bug


#### Steps to reproduce (preferably a link to a GitHub repo with a repro project): 

1. Build a project with MVC producing some views with `/p:Deterministic=true` 
2. Copy `Project.Views.dll` and `Project.dll`
3. Build project again using flag
4. Compare the two DLLs to the new build - `Project.dll` will have no difference whereas `Project.Views.dll` will be different


#### Description of the problem:

The razor compiled code is not deterministic. This means that building the same source code twice will result in different outputs.
We use `/p:Deterministic=true` to ensure that our build output is the same for the same source code. This is super helpful in our Service Fabric applications where we do not bump the version number up when the code did not change for a service.

#### Version of `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc` or `Microsoft.AspNetCore.App` or `Microsoft.AspNetCore.All`: 

2.1.0


It looks like there is a `/deterministic+` flag set in the RazorCoreCompile but that doesn't seem to do what is expected?

Issues.Title: ASP.NET Core tag helpers don't allow me to escape attributes annotated with @
Issues.Body:
Hello guys.

While migrating an existing app, I've noticed that the new tag helpers won't let me escape attributes annotated with  @. In my case, I have an existing MVC 5 app that I'm migrating to the ASP.NET Core. The existing code looked like this:

```html
<form action="@Url.Action(...)" @@submit="save()">
```

The server side is trying to use the shortcut notation for Vue's v-on: and the generated HTML looked like this:

```html
<form action="/..." @submit="save()">
```

When this view got migrated to ASP.NET Core, the code was changed to look like this:

```html
<form asp-action="..." asp-controller="..." @@submit="save()">
```

However, now the @¬´submit attribute isn't outputted (it's simply discarded from the generated HTML).

Is this a bug? If that is not the case, how can I output attributes annotated with @?

 @Thanks.

Luis
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ASP.NET Core tag helpers don't allow me to escape attributes annotated with @" (#2441)

Issues.Title: Account/ConfirmEmail - NullReferenceException in Error.cshtml when providing incorrect token
Issues.Body:
**Description**
The issue is related to Individual Accounts Authentication template. It seems that providing incorrect authentication code for ConfirmEmail action in AccountController (e.g. token which already expired) should result in displaying error page. However, Razor throws an exception while generating the default error view:

```
NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
AspNetCore._Views_Shared_Error_cshtml+<ExecuteAsync>d__0.MoveNext() in Error.cshtml, line 9
```

**Steps to reproduce**
1. Create new project with Individual Accounts Authentication template.
2. Run the application.
3. Register any user via the registration form.
4. Retrieve UserId of the registered user.
5. Try to confirm email with incorrect token, e.g. http://localhost:PORT/Account/ConfirmEmail?UserId={UserId}&Code=INVALID_CODE

**Further technical details**
It's probably caused by the last line in ConfirmEmail action in AccountController:
```
var result = await _userManager.ConfirmEmailAsync(user, code);
return View(result.Succeeded ? "ConfirmEmail" : "Error");
```

When invalid token is passed, Error view is not provided with `ErrorViewModel`. When `Model` is accessed in 9th line of Error.cshtml (`@if (Model.ShowRequestId)`), it throws NullReferenceException.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Account/ConfirmEmail - NullReferenceException in Error.cshtml when providing incorrect token" (#865)

Issues.Title: IEmailSender should have explicitly named parameters for html vs plain text
Issues.Body:
There have been a number of people reporting bugs about the email confirmation link in the StarterWeb template not working.

This is happening because people implement IEmailSender and don't realize that the message being passed in is html. When they send the email as plain text the confirmation link does not work because of the url encoding.

I think the "message" parameter of SendEmailAsync should be renamed to htmlMessage and possibly should have an additional parameter for "plainTextMessage" and both should be passed in from AccountController.

This would make it more clear to implementors of IEmailSender what kind of string(s) they are dealing with and how to correctly implement it.

related issues:
https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2152
https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2217
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "IEmailSender should have explicitly named parameters for html vs plain text" (#868)

https://github.com/aspnet/Templates/blob/f237bb024e1c8f05a7d78c215be2224022d2c153/template_feed/Microsoft.DotNet.Web.ProjectTemplates.2.0/content/StarterWeb-CSharp/Controllers/AccountController.cs#L443

Issues.Body: The Razor Pages Identity template turns on Lockout by default, unlike the MVC one.  This comment is left over from the MVC one and it no longer lines up with what is configured in the template.  I've reworded it to be accurate.  I can change it to just remove the comment all together if you want.

Issues.Body:
[Enabling QR Code generation for authenticator apps](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/security/authentication/identity-enable-qrcodes)

That should be supported in the templates like [SMS 2FA](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/security/authentication/2fa) used to be. 

requested by customer in [Enabling QR Code generation for authenticator apps](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/security/authentication/identity-enable-qrcodes) comments
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "QR Codes should be supported in templates" (#869)

Issues.Title: Cannot update @angular to 4.3.0+ (trying to update to 4.3.6)
Issues.Body:
After updating angular to 4.3.6, an internal server error begins to throw "NodeInvocationException: Can't resolve all parameters for HttpXsrfCookieExtractor."

Steps to reproduce:
1. cmd to c:\
2. dotnet --version 
_2.0.0_
3. mkdir dummy
4. cd dummy
5. dotnet new angular
6. dotnet restore
7. npm install
8. dotnet run (prove it works)
8a. ctrl+c to stop the server/build
9. update all @angular from "4.2.5" to "4.3.6"
10. npm update
11. dotnet run
...You should now crash... (see below)
12. change 4.3.6 back to 4.2.5 and 
repeat 10 and 11.
You should now work again.

Please let me know i there's anything else i can provide to help. Thank you!

Hi,

Issues.Title: Can't compile the devextreme-angular package in the Production mode using the ASP.NET Core 2.0 Angular template
Issues.Body:
This issue relates to the [one](https://github.com/DevExpress/devextreme-angular/issues/534). I've created an Angular application using .NET Core 2.0. The issue is reproducible regardless if I use Visual Studio 2017 15.3 or `dotnet new angular`. Everything works fine in the Development mode. But, once I publish my application with the [DevExtreme Angular](https://github.com/DevExpress/devextreme-angular) package using `dotnet publish -c Release`, I'm getting the following error:

```
      ERROR in ./$$_gendir/~/devextreme-angular/ui/data-grid.ngfactory.ts
      Module parse failed: D:\FromCustomers\GH534\NGCore\NGCore\$$_gendir\node_modules\devextreme-angular\ui\data-grid.ngfactory.ts Unexpected token (63:38)
      You may need an appropriate loader to handle this file type.
      | import * as i52 from 'devextreme-angular/core/iterable-differ-helper';
      | import * as i53 from 'devextreme-angular/core/nested-option';
      | export const DxDataGridModuleNgFactory:i0.NgModuleFactory<i1.DxDataGridModule> = i0.‚ïî‚ï°cmf(i1.DxDataGridModule,
      |     ([] as any[]),(_l:any) => {
      |       return i0.‚ïî‚ï°mod([i0.‚ïî‚ï°mpd(512,i0.ComponentFactoryResolver,i0.‚ïî‚ï°CodegenComponentFactoryResolver,
       @ ./$$_gendir/ClientApp/app/components/fetchdata/fetchdata.component.ngfactory.ts 8:0-102
       @ ./$$_gendir/ClientApp/app/app.module.server.ngfactory.ts
       @ ./ClientApp/boot.server.ts
D:\FromCustomers\GH534\NGCore\NGCore\NGCore.csproj(41,5): error MSB3073: The command "node node_modules/webpack/bin/webpack.js --env.prod" exited with code 2.
```

I added

```
"devextreme": "^17.1.5",
"devextreme-angular": "^17.1.5",
```

to the `package.json` file. Then, I added DevExtreme CSS files to the `webpack.config.vendor.js` as

```
const nonTreeShakableModules = [
    'bootstrap',
    'bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.css',
    'es6-promise',
    'es6-shim',
    'event-source-polyfill',
    'jquery',
    'devextreme/dist/css/dx.common.css',
    'devextreme/dist/css/dx.light.css'
];
```

If instead of the following line in the webpack.config.js file

```
{ test: /\.ts$/, include: /ClientApp/, use: isDevBuild ? ['awesome-typescript-loader?silent=true', 'angular2-template-loader'] : '@ngtools/webpack' },
```

I use

```
{ test: /\.ts$/, use: isDevBuild ? ['awesome-typescript-loader?silent=true', 'angular2-template-loader'] : '@ngtools/webpack' },
```

or

```
{ test: /\.ts$/, include: /ClientApp/, use: ['awesome-typescript-loader?silent=true', 'angular2-template-loader'] },
```

everything works fine. A similar configuration in a project created using Angular CLI works fine as well.

The attached `NGCore` project illustrates the issue and `test-app` created with Angular CLI illustrates that this works in a standard Angular CLI project after I call `ng eject`.

What can be the problem here? Is it in DevExtreme modules or in your webpack configuration?
[test-app.zip](https://github.com/aspnet/Templates/files/1240256/test-app.zip)
[NGCore.zip](https://github.com/aspnet/Templates/files/1240259/NGCore.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Can't compile the devextreme-angular package in the Production mode using the ASP.NET Core 2.0 Angular template" (#863)

Issues.Title: Razor Page templates use fully qualified name
Issues.Body:
The constructor uses the FQN when it's not necessary. For example:

See [Pages/Movie/Index.cshtml.cs](https://github.com/aspnet/Docs/blob/master/aspnetcore/tutorials/razor-pages/razor-pages-start/sample/RazorPagesMovie/Pages/Movie/Index.cshtml.cs#L14-L16)

`using RazorPagesMovie.Models;` is in the template.

To repro - follow the [Razor Pages tutorial](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/tutorials/razor-pages/model)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Razor Page templates use fully qualified name " (#858)
